Situation1: They handle a busy checkout with a long queue during peak hours.
Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story: The line at the supermarket stretched past the candy racks, customers shifting impatiently as I scanned groceries and counted change. My manager’s eyes flicked to the clock, urging me to keep the line moving. Every beep of the register reminded me of the time—Jummah was approaching, and as the imam, I was expected to deliver the sermon. The congregation counted on me for guidance, especially today, when the topic was unity in hardship. Yet, the store was short-staffed, and my manager had already asked me to stay through the rush. I knew a guest speaker was ready at the mosque, but I also knew the community valued my presence and words. My hands moved automatically, but my mind raced between the demands of my job and my duty to my faith. Each expectation pulled at me, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides, and I felt the tension knotting in my chest as the clock ticked closer to prayer time.
